Applications are due to O&M room 202 by 5PM on February 17th, 2014 and will be followed by a round of interviews. Please encourage everyone you know to apply this week!!\n\nURT serves the college by assisting in the recruitment of high school students interested in the College of Geosciences. Events URT members participate in include Aggieland Saturday, student visits and other recruitment activities. Undergraduate Recruitment Team members receive a scholarship once they meet program requirements.\n\nGeoX is a one-week, hands-on and field-based program designed to introduce high-achieving high school juniors and seniors to the world of geosciences. Our students spend the week overseeing the camp\u2019s activities and sharing their passion for the geosciences. Counselors receive a $500 stipend along with meals, room and board included during the program.\"\n\nApplications for both URT and GeoX are available in the Student Opportunities photo album on the Tamu Geosciences Student-Life account or by emailing recruitment@geos.tamu.edu by request. These activities offer outstanding opportunities for students to serve their university and to contribute to the continuing advancement of their college. If you have any questions, feel free to contact Dr. Garcia at garcias5@tamu.edu or 979.845.3651."}

Remoras or suckerfishes attach to objects or large ocean organisms, such as sharks.  When a remora attaches to a glider, it adds additional weight to the glider.  The additional weight makes  it difficult for the glider to continue its yos (see picture).  If the glider is unable to surface after 13.5 hours, it will eject a 500 gram weight to help it surface.  Ejecting a weight will end a glider's mission, which is what happened to Glider 308 on 1 November 2013.", "application": {"name": "Photos", "id": "2305272732"}, "link": "https://www.facebook.com/TamuGergGliders/photos/a.235073719994239.1073741828.230267970474814/241681396000138/?type=1", "object_id": "241681396000138", "story_tags": {"0": [{"length": 43, "offset": 0, "type": "page", "id": "30730623774", "name": "Texas A&M University College of Geosciences"}], "51": [{"length": 36, "offset": 51, "type": "page", "id": "230267970474814", "name": "GERG Gliders at Texas A&M University"}]}, "created_time": "2013-12-02T21:16:18+0000", "message": "Be sure to like the GERG Gliders at Texas A&M's Facebook page for some interesting facts about the Slocum gliders that we have travelling around the Gulf of Mexico, their research and data that they send back to us on land. {"picture": "https://fbexternal-a.akamaihd.net/safe_image.php?d=AQB90DSb3Y4j1-Wk&w=154&h=154&url=http%3A%2F%2Fmedia.npr.org%2Fassets%2Fimg%2F2013%2F11%2F11%2Fnoaa-chart_wide-878ab07d61ed1fafad0e638882e46e08c995f642.jpg", "from": {"category": "Education", "name": "Texas A&M University College of Geosciences", "category_list": [{"id": "108051929285833", "name": "College & University"}], "id": "30730623774"}, "name": "Why Typhoon Haiyan Caused So Much Damage", "privacy": {"value": ""}, "actions": [{"link": "https://www.facebook.com/30730623774/posts/10151798978013775", "name": "Comment"}, {"link": "https://www.facebook.com/30730623774/posts/10151798978013775", "name": "Like"}], "updated_time": "2013-11-21T23:02:37+0000", "caption": "www.npr.org", "link": "http://www.npr.org/2013/11/11/244572227/why-typhoon-haiyan-caused-so-much-damage?ft=1&f=1001", "likes": {"paging": {"cursors": {"after": "MTAwMDAxMTY5NDE3NzA4", "before": "MTM4NjU5NjkzNw=="}}, "data": [{"id": "1386596937", "name": "Elora Arana"}, {"id": "102337189813993", "name": "Texas A&M University Libraries"}, {"id": "100001169417708", "name": "Angela Saavedra"}]}, "created_time": "2013-11-21T23:02:37+0000", "message": "\"Dr. John Nielsen-Gammon, the Texas state climatologist at Texas A&M University, says gusts blew up to 230 mph, which is as fast as a speeding race car.\"\n\nDr. Robert Korty, whose research includes hurricane-ocean interactions, gave this statement about Typhoon Haiyan: \"Super Typhoon Haiyan was the fifth tropical cyclone in 2013 to reach an intensity equivalent to a category 5 hurricane, which is about the average number of storms that become this intense each a year.  To be one of the few storms to reach this intensity, a storm must have favorable conditions surrounding it, including warm water temperatures, high humidity in the middle part of the atmosphere, and small differences in upper and lower level winds steering the storm.  \n\nThese storms form over tropical oceans, often far from land, so we rely on satellites to measure some properties from which we can estimate their intensity.  Based on these estimates, Haiyan may have had stronger surface winds than in any storm previously observed (195 mph with gusts to 235 mph), but we no longer fly aircraft into storms to directly measure their intensity in the western Pacific, so we have no way to be certain of its exact winds. Regardless of the precise wind speed, the storm was incredibly intense and did immense damage in the Philippines, where it resulted in a tragic number of casualties.\"", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yq/r/SC2ZmEkfI-X.png", "type": "link", "id": "30730623774_10151798978013775", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "\"We had a triple whammy of surge, very high winds and strong rainfall,\" says one climate scientist."}

Changes in the global climate are not recent and along its more than 4 billion years the climate has warmed and cooled. Over the decades, these satellites have provided invaluable information, and the vantage point of space has provided new perspectives on Earth. This book celebrates Earth\u2019s aesthetic beauty in the patterns, shapes, colors, and textures of the land, oceans, ice, and atmosphere. The book features 75 stunning images of Earth from the Terra, Landsat 5, Landsat 7, EO-1, and Aqua satellites. Sensors on these satellites can measure light outside of the visible range, so the images show more than what is visible to the naked eye. The images are intended for viewing enjoyment rather than scientific interpretation. In order to monitor and have some photographic records of the presence of wildcats at the Soltis Center, we installed a camera trap in one of the trails. So far the results in the very first week are very encouraging: we already recorded the presence of an ocelot (Leopardus pardalis) and a puma or cougar (Puma concolor). According to the expert in tropical wildcats Dr. Eduardo Carrillo, Director of the International Institute in Conservation and Management of Wildlife of the Universidad Nacional de Costa Rica, helped out positively identify the cats. We are really pleased to share these pictures and encourage you to keep visiting our web page since we expect soon to have evidence of the presence of the jaguar, which has also been reported around the Soltis Center rain forests.\"\n\nDr. Christopher Houser\nDept. of Geography\nTexas A&M University", "updated_time": "2013-04-25T21:25:54+0000", "type": "photo", "id": "30730623774_10151404933723775", "status_type": "shared_story", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif"}

Would you like to enhance your resume while refining your professional skills? The Student Geosciences' Council is holding an informational this Tuesday April 16 at 5:30 in Room 112 at O&M building, to fill leadership positions within the Council. The primary objective of the Student Geosciences' Council is to provide a representative voice of all geosciences students; it works to increase geosciences awareness through its programs and events; and it fosters the professional advancement of all geosciences students within the College of Geosciences. The Council will participate in the creation and organization of speaker panels, college events, and a student run Career Fair for the College of Geosciences. Participation and involvement within the Council will not only allow students to further enhance their professional development, network with former and current students, but will be a crucial asset in pioneering the success of the student council.\n\nTo apply, fill out the application attached to this email and turn it in to the front desk of the Dean\u2019s office on 2nd Floor O&M.\n\nIf you are unable to attend the informational and would like additional information please contact \nKaitlyn Simpson\nVice-President- Interior\nkaitlynmarie15@tamu.edu", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif", "type": "link", "id": "30730623774_293432907457104", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "Our first informational will be for recruitment of College of Geosciences students to hold Chairs in the newly formed Student Geosciences Council. Check out spaceweather.com for more information about the sun\u2019s activity. NASA also made a smart phone app called 3D Sun that allows you to see images of the sun and provides news alerts of important solar events. You can find this free app on both iTunes and Android Market.\n\niPhone and iPad - http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/3d-sun/id347089078\n\nAndroid - https://market.android.com/details?id=org.threeDsun", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yq/r/SC2ZmEkfI-X.png", "type": "link", "id": "30730623774_293150124036981", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "The northern lights came to the Deep South on Monday night, making them visible hundreds of miles farther south than they normally would be."}

The San Saba, Texas native is known for several contributions to geology and geophysics such as a mathematical demonstration of the plasticity of rock and detailed information about the capacities of oil and natural gas reservoirs. Expedition 337 is part of a long-term multi-disciplinary experiment that builds on work begun during Expedition 301. The main goals are to evaluate hydrogeologic properties within the ocean crust, determine how fluids move within an active hydrothermal system, establish links between fluid circulation, alteration and geomicrobial processes, and determine relations between seismic and hydrologic properties.
